turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Indian Head gold pieces.
turn.1: What was the most important aspect of the Indian Head gold piece program?
turn.2: Barber opposed bringing in outsiders, citing delays in the preparation of the earlier gold coin designs which he attributed to the Saint-Gaudens studio: "it is entirely unnecessary to trouble Mr. Hering any further, unless another year is to be wasted in vain endeavor".
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: On January 3, 1908, Leach wrote to Hering to inform him that all work would be done by the Mint.
turn.5: Was there any controversy with the program?
turn.6: The President's friend, Dr. William Sturgis Bigelow, had been in Japan for most of 1907; on his return to his Boston home he heard about the Saint-Gaudens coinage from Senator Henry Cabot Lodge.
turn.8: Bigelow was one of a number of Roosevelt's friends given early specimens of the double eagle.
turn.10: He wrote to the President on January 8, 1908, praising the Saint-Gaudens coins and stating that he was working with a Boston sculptor, Bela Pratt, on an idea that would allow coins to be struck in high relief.
turn.11: What was the result of that?
turn.12: Pieces struck in this manner would have the designs protected from wear and be able to stack easily (both problems with high relief coins).
